questions.text: Which chamber's anterior wall forms most of the sternocostal surface of the heart?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The heart has three important surfaces: an anterior surface, a diaphragmatic surface, and a pulmonary surface. The anterior surface, or sternocostal surface, is mostly made up of the right ventricle. The diaphragmatic surface is mostly the left ventricle, but a little bit of the right ventricle sits on the diaphragm as well. Finally, the pulmonary surface, which is on the left, is mostly made up of the left ventricle

choices.text: In the second left intercostal space
In the second right intercostal space
In the fifth left intercostal space

questions.text: The heart sound associated with the mitral valve is best heard:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The mitral valve is best auscultated at the apex of the heart, located in the fifth left intercostal space at the midclavicular line (Option D is correct)
  • The jugular notch is a suprasternal structure, not related to heart valve auscultation (Option A ruled out)
  • The second left intercostal space is used for auscultating the pulmonary valve (Option B ruled out)
  • The second right intercostal space corresponds to the aortic valve auscultation site (Option C ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Mitral valve auscultation point: 5th left intercostal space, midclavicular line
  • Valve auscultation sites do not match anatomical location but are based on direction of blood flow.

questions.text: Which heart valve has leaflets described as "anterior, left and right"?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The pulmonary valve has three semilunar cusps named anterior, left, and right, distinguishing it from the aortic valve (Option B is correct)
  • The aortic valve also has three cusps but they are named right, left, and posterior, not anterior (Option A ruled out)
  • The left atrioventricular valve (mitral valve) has two cusps: anterior and posterior, not three (Option C ruled out)
  • The right atrioventricular valve (tricuspid valve) has three leaflets named anterior, posterior, and septal, not left and right (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Pulmonary valve has anterior, left, and right cusps
  • Aortic valve has right, left, and posterior cusps
  • Cusp names help differentiate aortic vs pulmonary valves.

questions.text: You are caring for a 68-year-old male who has copious amounts of fluid in the left pleural cavity due to acute pleurisy. When you examine him as he sits up in bed (trunk upright), where would the fluid tend to accumulate?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The costodiaphragmatic recess is the lowest part of the pleural cavity in an upright person, making it the most common site for fluid accumulation (Option A is correct)
  • The costomediastinal recess is located anteriorly near the heart and is less dependent, so fluid does not typically pool here (Option B ruled out)
  • The cupola is the apex of the pleural cavity, situated above the first rib; being the highest point, fluid will not collect here (Option C ruled out)
  • The hilar reflection is the area around the root of the lung, not a dependent area for fluid accumulation (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Costodiaphragmatic recess is the most dependent part of the pleural cavity in the upright position
  • Important site for pleural effusion detection on chest X-ray.

questions.text: A patient was stabbed 23 times. One such stab wound was present in the left supraclavicular fossa, piercing his left lung. Which of the following provides the vertebral attachment to the fascia present here?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The suprapleural membrane (Sibson's fascia) reinforces the apex of the lung and covers the cupola of the pleura
  • This fascia extends from the transverse process of C7 vertebra to the inner border of the first rib, providing structural support (Option C is correct)
  • C5 and C6 are too superior and do not serve as the direct attachment site for the suprapleural membrane (Options A and B ruled out)
  • C8 is part of the brachial plexus roots but does not serve as the anchoring vertebral level for this fascia (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Suprapleural membrane (Sibson’s fascia) is anchored to C7 transverse process
  • It provides apical pleura protection and may be pierced in penetrating trauma to the supraclavicular fossa.

choices.text: Attached to the inner border of 2nd rib

questions.text: Which among the following is incorrect regarding Sibsons's fascia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Sibson’s fascia, or the suprapleural membrane, is a thickened extension of the endothoracic fascia
  • It is attached to the inner border of the first rib and the transverse process of C7, not the second rib (Option A is incorrect and thus correct answer)
  • It covers the apical part of the lung, providing protection (Option B is correct)
  • It is derived from or associated with the scalenus minimus muscle, when present (Option C is correct)
  • Important vessels, like the subclavian artery and vein, pass above the fascia, not through it (Option D is correct)

Key Takeaways:

  • Sibson’s fascia reinforces the cupola of pleura
  • It is attached to the 1st rib and C7 transverse process
  • Incorrect association with 2nd rib is a common distractor.
